title: 30% of drivers have seen road rage attack in past year
text:
Nearly a third (30 per cent) of motorists have witnessed physical abuse related to a driving incident in the past 12 months, a new survey suggests.

The RAC poll also indicates nearly half (49 per cent) have seen verbal abuse dished out to another motorist this year, while 60 per cent think road rage is more common than a decade ago.

Drivers who feel aggrieved 'all too often' use hand gestures towards other motorists which lead to confrontations, the automotive services company said.

A new survey suggests that half of motorists have witnessed verbal abuse related to a driving incident in the past 12 months

The proportion of motorists who say their biggest concern on the road is the aggressive behaviour of other drivers has doubled from to 8 per cent over the past 12 months.

The RAC's annual Report On Motoring also suggests 51 per cent of drivers aged 17 to 24 years are still using their phone illegally behind the wheel, while 19 per cent of motorists admit they think or know they have driven while over the drink-drive limit in the last year.

Some 1,753 drivers were surveyed in May and June for the research.

RAC road safety spokesman Simon Williams said fears associated with the behaviour of other drivers are growing due to a combination of factors such as the pressure of modern life, a reliance on the car for so many journeys and record traffic volumes leading to congestion.

He went on: 'Perhaps it is also the case that our tolerance of other people who make mistakes while driving is falling.

'A quick sorry in the form of an apologetic wave could go a long way to taking the heat out of a situation.

'Unfortunately, all too often it is a hand gesture of another sort that leads to an unpleasant car confrontation.'

Almost one in three said they've seen road rage confrontations turn physical in the last year, with most believing that driver fall outs are on the rise

Peter Brabin, head of training at Bill Plant driving school, added: 'It is easy to get frustrated whilst driving however, that isn’t going to help yourself, your passengers nor other road users.

'Mistakes will occur whilst driving and it is important for us to remember that we are simply getting from A to B.

'Let’s all get home safely every day and have consideration for other people on the road.'
